intro: Hexalectris spicata var. arizonica, commonly known as the Arizona false morel, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Rhamnaceae and is characterized by its unique, cap-like, hollow stem that resembles a morel mushroom. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in desert and mountainous regions. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in clusters, which are pollinated by bees and other insects. The species is adapted to arid environments and exhibits a short growing season, often blooming in late spring or early summer.
